content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks interesting and the environment of the game is not very common. I like it :)

Hi!

First of all, I think that the puzzle is very interesting. I liked it a lot!

However, I think it is way too hard for a clash. It took me more than half an hour to solve it (around 45 min including reading and understanding the problem). While I may not be the faster programmer around, I don't think that it is possible to solve it in 15 minutes, and forget about the 5 minutes that clashes are supposed to take.

I don't think it is an issue with your puzzle, but with path-finding and optimization in general, which are not that easy to code. Thus, I don't think my suggestions will help a lot, but here we go:

* I would try to simplify the statement, in order to make it easier to read and understand:
    - Use only '_' for platforms and '#' for empty cells. There is no real difference between floor and platform, so the same symbol may be used. Also, the position for the bowl is given by the coordinates, so there is not need to draw it. 
    - I think the movement pattern of the cat can be clearer on a `monospace` grid representing the cells:
```
[ ][ ][+][ ][ ]
[ ][+][+][+][ ]
[+][+][C][+][+]
[ ][+][+][+][ ]
[ ][ ][+][ ][ ]
```
* It would be convenient to specify that the bowl is always reachable.

These suggestions aim to make it faster to read and understand, but I don't think that they really make a huge different. IMO you should simplify the problem, even if it loses part of the narrative, or make it a puzzle (maybe you can add a second bowl if you think it is too easy right now, but I'd say it is OK)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's fun!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very interesting puzzle, I like it :)

it is a nice puzzle but took me way more than 5 minutes to code my path finder.
maybe i was sub-efficient.

i think it is a good puzzle but too complex for a clash of code.
I noticed the downvotes, but I would gladly receive some feedbacks, to let me know what could be improved on this clash, or advices for my future puzzles. Thanks :)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I find this puzzle very interesting! Well done, can't wait to try it out when it's finished!
looks good to me!

The puzzle looks interesting!

Input section
* Please format the six variables inside the brackets too.

Constraints section
* "Any kind of move (short or long jump, on the floor or to a platform) counts as one single move." This is not a constraint - this is a puzzle specification. Please move it to Goal section.

Goal section
* Please specify which cell is the origin (x = 0, y = 0).
* Please specify which directions x and y increase respectively. (In many CodinGame puzzles, x increases when moving from left to right, and y increases when moving from top to bottom instead of from bottom to top.)
* While "up to two cells" is perfectly good English, I am not sure if one may misinterpret it as "up" as in "up/down" (it still makes sense even when followed by "in a straight direction"). I would suggest to change "up" to "at most". (Not a big issue though, as you've included a graphical representation of where a cat can jump.)
* A bit odd in the choice of having the first row as the floor (I guess it has something to do with the direction y changes?), as that means the floor is at the top rather than at the bottom in the graphical representation... It doesn't affect the solvability of the puzzle, though.

Thanks.

Thank you for your great feedback !

I've fixed the Input and Constraints section.

For the Goal section, I've added those two lines :
"(0, 0) is the top left origin.
(w - 1, h - 1) is the bottom right."
Is it clear enough ?

About your last observation, I agree with you but I wasn't sure of what would be the less confusing between :
- having the floor as the first matrix row and therefore, having to increase y to go up. But that way it looks odd in the graphical representation...
-  or having the floor as the last row with a graphical representation that makes sense but having to decrease y to go up, which could be odd too, don't you think ?
Maybe there is a better third option that I'm not seeing ?

This is way too hard for a clash.
No one is solving this in 5 minutes. 15 minutes is still not long enough.

I just got this as a clash and had to just do a hacky solution (took (the manhattan distance/2).ceil as the path distance) and got 57% this way. It's not fun or fair.

This is a great idea for a puzzle, but for a clash it's way too complicated. If you want people to solve a hard problem in a clash (i.e. pathfinding in a maze), then you can't make it complicated in other ways:
1. the fact that the cats can jump more than 1 square at a time and move diagonally = very complicated!
2. the long backstory about the two cats = distracting, takes time to read and wastes precious coding time.
3. path-finding for two cats = two separate path-finding problems that then need to be compared.

If you wanted this to be a clash, then it needed to be much simpler and easier for people to immediately focus on trying to solve the difficult problem of double path-finding. Way too hard.

Thank you !
I agree that this is a hard one as a CoC for many players, but I knew it wasn't original enough for an easy puzzle since there is already a lot of path-finding puzzles.
And I didn't find a way to simplify it without making it less interesting
Thank you ! :)
Thanks, glad you like it !

Just got this in a clash again and even after having seen it before, it's still way too hard for a clash.

It takes about 5 minutes to even understand the problem (even after having seen it before). Then trying to code up a workable solution takes 5-10 minutes, and there's basically no time to debug issues at the end.

This time I managed to JUST finish in time, but my solution was actually timing out on the "Giant Cat Wall" test. Thankfully it passed all the validators and I got 100%, but no one else in my clash got anywhere near solving it. 2nd place seems to have just found some hacky heuristic to get 42%.

https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/41338826514eec26a6d4140c55951101444b7ed

Here was my Ruby solution, using Breadth-First Search:

w, h = gets.split.map { |x| x.to_i }
warn$_
fx, fy, tx, ty, bx, by = gets.split.map { |x| x.to_i }
warn$_
a = h.times.map do
  r = wall_row = gets.chomp
  warn r
  r
end
qf = vf = [[fx, fy]]
qt = vt = [[tx, ty]]
# BFS
c = 0
until (qf+qt).include?([bx, by])
  c += 1
  of = qf.flat_map{|x, y|
    [[x+1, y],[x+2, y], [x-1, y], [x-2, y],
      [x, y+1],[x, y+2], [x, y-1], [x, y-2],
      [x+1,y+1], [x+1,y-1],[x-1,y+1],[x-1,y-1]].select{|i,j|
        (0...h) === j && (0...w) === i && a[j][i] != "#"
      }
  } - vf
  ot = qt.flat_map{|x, y|
    [[x+1, y],[x+2, y], [x-1, y], [x-2, y],
      [x, y+1],[x, y+2], [x, y-1], [x, y-2],
      [x+1,y+1], [x+1,y-1],[x-1,y+1],[x-1,y-1]].select{|i,j|
        (0...h) === j && (0...w) === i && a[j][i] != "#"
      }
  } - vt
  vf += qf
  vt += qt
  qf = of
  qt = ot
end
w = qf.include?([bx, by]) && qt.include?([bx, by]) ? "Tie" :
  qf.include?([bx, by]) ? "Flash" : "Tornade"
puts "#{c} #{w}"

Thank you, and the fixes are fine :)

Having y decrease down the way actually matches the usual (Cartesian) coordinate system, just that it's a little bit clumsier for coding a clash solution. I can't think of a better option, either. Let's see what the other moderators think :)

I was able to try out some puzzles since the creation of my clash, including some with 2D matrix and a graphical representation where, as you explained, I had to decrease y to go up. So I’ve decided to change that. Thank you for your advice, I think it’s better that way :)
I do like the way it is right now, too. Easy to parse and easy to visualize :)
